title: Protesters ‘swarm’ London’s banks to protest investment in fossil fuels
text:
Extinction Rebellion protesters are making their presence known in the City of London (Picture: Extinction Rebellion/ PA)

Extinction Rebellion protesters will target financial institutions today, with activists planning to ‘swarm’ the Bank of England.

The on-going demonstration will cause ‘maximum disruption’ to the City of London as a second week of civil disobedience begins.

Banks and financial institutions by St Paul’s, Liverpool Street and Southwark are expected to face ‘mass swarming’ in which ‘rebel hives’ will ‘spread out to pollinate the morning commute’.

Protesters are calling on city workers to ‘help highlight the impact of financial institutions on the climate and ecological emergency outside the UK’.

They argue that big banks heavily invest in and profit from coal, gas and mineral extraction, as well as intensive farming and logging.

Activists have vowed to ‘swarm’ the City of London today (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

They are calling on city workers to take a stand (Picture: PA)

A trial of the financial sector will be held this afternoon (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

They have been there since 7am this morning (Picture: PA)

Activists have been blocking Bank from 7am this morning and a trial of the financial sector will be held this afternoon.

They were filmed sitting outside the Bank of England, while others drummed in the rain by the tube station.

Former city worker and XR protester Andrew Medhurst said: ‘I decided to give up a 30-year career in financial services because I could no longer ignore the climate and ecological emergency.

‘I held senior positions managing risk at both HSBC and Lloyds Bank and I know that banks would never take the level of risk that the UK government appears willing to take with the safety of its citizens and the futures of our children and grandchildren.’

As of 12pm yesterday, 1,309 people have been arrested across London since XR protests began last week.

Some activists have already been arrested (Picture: PA)

They are taking aim at London’s financial institutions (Picture: PA)

The protests have been going on for two weeks (Picture: PA)

As of yesterday, 1,309 people had been arrested (Picture: Reuters)

Each day different sectors are targeted (Picture: Getty Images)

More than 1460 people have been arrested in international demonstrations, causing the overall total to surpass 2770.

On Saturday, it was revealed that a Belgian princess had been detained in London during a sit-in in Trafalgar Square on Thursday.

Princess Esmerelda, 63, is the daughter of the late Leopold III and his second wife Lilian Baels, Princess of Rethy.

She was questioned in the back of a police van and held for around five hours, writing online afterwards: ‘Today along with many other protesters I was arrested and put in police custody.

‘The climate emergency calls on all of us to put pressure on governments to act with urgency.’

Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick warned the protests take police away from knife crime (Picture: AFP)

London is leading the protests (Picture: Getty Images)

More arrests are expected to take place this week (Picture: Rex Features)

Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick has insisted Scotland Yard has enough cells to hold arrested activists.

However, she warned that officers were being taken away from tackling knife crime or safeguarding children.

She also said protesters were ‘utterly irresponsible and completely unreasonable’ for their determination to take over and occupy important arterial roads in London.

Urging them to only demonstrate in the pedestrian area of Trafalgar Square, she added: ‘Protest lawfully or go home.’

description: Extinction Rebellion are protesting financial institutions in the City of London, such as the Bank of England, for fossil fuel investment.
